title: Marilyn Crispell, Gerry Hemingway - Table of Changes (2015)
description:
Marilyn Crispell / Gerry Hemingway
Table of Changes
2015 - Intakt Records: Intakt CD 246 
http://www.intaktrec.ch/246-a.htm

* Marilyn Crispell: piano
* Gerry Hemingway: drums, percussion, vibraphone
 
http://marilyncrispell.com/ 
http://www.gerryhemingway.com/

Â· 1, 2, 3, 6 recorded on May 5, 2013, at 2013 Ulrichsberg Kaleidophon
  in Austria. Engineer: Alfred Reiter.
Â· 4 recorded on May 14, 2013, at La Chapelle du Mejan at the 19th Edition
  of Jazz in Arles in France. Engineer: Boris Darley.
Â· 5, 7 recorded on May 16, 2013, at the Bimhuis, Amsterdam, Netherlands.
  Engineer: Olivier Schutte.
Â· 8 recorded on May 12, 2013, at the Europa Jazz Festival in Le Mans, France.
  Engineer: Jean-Marc Foussat.


Reviews
~~~~~~~

By John Fordham 
http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jun/25/marilyn-crispellgerry-hemingway-table-of-changes-review

With Affinities in 2011, the partnership of former Anthony Braxton players
Marilyn Crispell (piano) and Gerry Hemingway (drums) produced improv-duo music
of power, precision and lyricism. Table of Changes is another live album, drawn
from four dates on their 2013 European tour. The tracks are all originals,
highlighting the playersâ€™ emotional as well as technical range, with the only
cover being Evâ€™ry Time We Say Goodbye â€“ interpreted in solemn, spacey chords
and percussion tapestries until the melody coalesces at the end. Crispellâ€™s
strength, decisiveness and energy often surface in the turbulent chordwork that
rolls and rings against Hemingwayâ€™s needling cymbal sounds and pummelling
drums, but sheâ€™s as likely to float glistening treble tones over the drummerâ€™s
vibraphone glow or the pings of finger-cymbals. The dreamy and then darkening
Night Passing focuses on Crispellâ€™s use of space and harmonic sophistication;
Hemingwayâ€™s rubbed-metal sounds and ghostly nasal singing emphasise the title
implications of Windy City while Crispell rhapsodises classically. Itâ€™s an
uncannily attuned partnership.

--
